elements.content: The reaction of Ni­(mnt)2 (mnt = 1,2-dicyano-1,2-ethylenedithiolate) with CuI in THF results in the formation of a Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4 unit with an eight-membered Cu4I4 crown motif. Coordination polymers with Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4 building units, having doubly bridged 1-D chains, were formed with bulky NBu4 counterions. To pack the bulky NBu4 cations into the crystal structure, no direct interactions between the 1-D chain structures are observed. When the bulky NBu4 cations are exchanged for small sodium cations, direct interactions between the 1-D chain structures dominate. A doubly bridged 2-D sheet structure is formed through the bridging of the cyano groups of the Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4 units of neighboring 1-D chain structures by sodium atoms. The monomeric [Na2(18-crown-16)]2[Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4] complex is formed when the sodium cations of the 2-D sheet structure are captured by 18-crown-6. The configuration of the coordination polymer or the monomer is controlled through the selection of the appropriate countercation to the Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4 building unit. Furthermore, the eight-membered Cu4I4 crown motifs in the 2-D sheet structure captures sodium cations. In this regard, we propose that the flexible Cu4I4 crown motif is capable of capturing atoms or molecules of various sizes; such a material may act as a useful molecular adsorbent through electrostatic interactions.
elements.clean_text: The reaction of Ni(mnt)2 (mnt = 1,2-dicyano-1,2-ethylenedithiolate) with CuI in THF results in the formation of a Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4 unit with an eight-membered Cu4I4 crown motif. Coordination polymers with Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4 building units, having doubly bridged 1-D chains, were formed with bulky NBu4 counterions. To pack the bulky NBu4 cations into the crystal structure, no direct interactions between the 1-D chain structures are observed. When the bulky NBu4 cations are exchanged for small sodium cations, direct interactions between the 1-D chain structures dominate. A doubly bridged 2-D sheet structure is formed through the bridging of the cyano groups of the Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4 units of neighboring 1-D chain structures by sodium atoms. The monomeric [Na2(18-crown-16)]2[Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4] complex is formed when the sodium cations of the 2-D sheet structure are captured by 18-crown-6. The configuration of the coordination polymer or the monomer is controlled through the selection of the appropriate countercation to the Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4 building unit. Furthermore, the eight-membered Cu4I4 crown motifs in the 2-D sheet structure captures sodium cations. In this regard, we propose that the flexible Cu4I4 crown motif is capable of capturing atoms or molecules of various sizes; such a material may act as a useful molecular adsorbent through electrostatic interactions.

elements.content: The reaction of Ni­(mnt)2 (mnt = 1,2-dicyano-1,2-ethylenedithiolate) with CuI in THF results in the formation of a Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4 unit with an eight-membered Cu4I4 crown motif. The successful formation of the coordination polymer or the monomer is controlled through the selection of the appropriate countercation to the Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4 building unit.
elements.clean_text: The reaction of Ni(mnt)2 (mnt = 1,2-dicyano-1,2-ethylenedithiolate) with CuI in THF results in the formation of a Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4 unit with an eight-membered Cu4I4 crown motif. The successful formation of the coordination polymer or the monomer is controlled through the selection of the appropriate countercation to the Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4 building unit.

elements.content: The construction of coordination polymers from metal ions with bridging organic ligands is one of the most attractive areas in materials research. Bis­(maleonitriledithiolato)-metalate complexes ([M­(mnt)2] n−, n = 1 or 2; mnt = 1,2-dicyano-1,2-ethylenedithiolate) are a widely studied family of dithiolene complexes. Attempts have been made to optimize the conducting and/or magnetic properties of M­(mnt)2 complexes by varying the metal and the cation. For instance, a large variety of M­(mnt)2 complex crystal-packing motifs are formed using various substituted ferrocene compounds. M­(mnt)2 bearing cyano groups acts as a good bridging ligand due to its moderate coordinating ability to copper­(I) ions. In our previous study, we reported the syntheses and structures of (NBu4)2[M­(mnt)2Cu4I4] mixed-metal coordination polymers (M = Ni (1), Pd (2), and Pt (3)). The Cu4I4 crown motif in complexes 1–3 consists of an eight-membered Cu4I4 ring supported by four sulfur atoms from the M­(mnt)2 moiety. In general, Cu4I4 units build cubane- or step-like molecular structures. The Cu4I4 crown motif, with an eight-membered Cu4I4 ring, was first found in complexes 1–3; these complexes form coordination polymers that are doubly bridged one-dimensional chains in which two copper atoms are coordinated to the nitrogen atoms of cyano groups in neighboring M­(mnt)2 moieties. No direct interactions are observed between these 1-D chain structures in order to accommodate the bulky NBu4 cations into the crystal structure.
elements.clean_text: The construction of coordination polymers from metal ions with bridging organic ligands is one of the most attractive areas in materials research. Bis(maleonitriledithiolato)-metalate complexes ([M(mnt)2] n-, n = 1 or 2; mnt = 1,2-dicyano-1,2-ethylenedithiolate) are a widely studied family of dithiolene complexes. Attempts have been made to optimize the conducting and/or magnetic properties of M(mnt)2 complexes by varying the metal and the cation. For instance, a large variety of M(mnt)2 complex crystal-packing motifs are formed using various substituted ferrocene compounds. M(mnt)2 bearing cyano groups acts as a good bridging ligand due to its moderate coordinating ability to copper(I) ions. In our previous study, we reported the syntheses and structures of (NBu4)2[M(mnt)2Cu4I4] mixed-metal coordination polymers (M = Ni (1), Pd (2), and Pt (3)). The Cu4I4 crown motif in complexes 1-3 consists of an eight-membered Cu4I4 ring supported by four sulfur atoms from the M(mnt)2 moiety. In general, Cu4I4 units build cubane- or step-like molecular structures. The Cu4I4 crown motif, with an eight-membered Cu4I4 ring, was first found in complexes 1-3; these complexes form coordination polymers that are doubly bridged one-dimensional chains in which two copper atoms are coordinated to the nitrogen atoms of cyano groups in neighboring M(mnt)2 moieties. No direct interactions are observed between these 1-D chain structures in order to accommodate the bulky NBu4 cations into the crystal structure.

elements.content: The crystal packing structure of complex 1 is shown in in which the 1-D chain structures and NBu4 cations are illustrated using ball-and-stick and space-filling models, respectively. The structural chains are aligned in the c-axis direction and are separated from each other by bulky NBu4 cations, as shown in . In this study, we assume that the connectivity and self-assembly of the Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4 building unit can be obtained through the selection of appropriate counter cations. In complexes 1–3, the bulky NBu4 cations prevent interactions between the 1-D-chain structures in the Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4-packed crystals. Therefore, the reaction of complex 1 with sodium cations instead of NBu4 cations is expected to change the crystal-packing motif. Here, we report the synthesis and characterization of the 2-D sheet structure of the eight-membered Cu4I4-crown-motif-containing coordination polymer of [Na­(THF)4]­[Na­(THF)3]­[Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4]­(THF) (4) obtained through self-assembly. The 2-D sheet structure in 4 was formed by exploiting the 1D-chain structures of Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4 that are bridged by sodium atoms through the cyano groups of their Ni­(mnt)2 moieties. Subsequently, in order to interrupt interactions among the Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4 building units in the crystal, complex 4 was reacted with a crown ether (18-crown-6), which captured the sodium cations through host–guest interactions. In fact, the Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4 monomer unit of [Na2(18-crown-16)]2[Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4] (5) was isolated through crystal packing. We determined that the Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4 building unit controls the dimensionality of the coordination polymer, from the monomer to the 2-D sheet structure.
elements.clean_text: The crystal packing structure of complex 1 is shown in  in which the 1-D chain structures and NBu4 cations are illustrated using ball-and-stick and space-filling models, respectively. The structural chains are aligned in the c-axis direction and are separated from each other by bulky NBu4 cations, as shown in . In this study, we assume that the connectivity and self-assembly of the Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4 building unit can be obtained through the selection of appropriate counter cations. In complexes 1-3, the bulky NBu4 cations prevent interactions between the 1-D-chain structures in the Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4-packed crystals. Therefore, the reaction of complex 1 with sodium cations instead of NBu4 cations is expected to change the crystal-packing motif. Here, we report the synthesis and characterization of the 2-D sheet structure of the eight-membered Cu4I4-crown-motif-containing coordination polymer of [Na(THF)4][Na(THF)3][Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4](THF) (4) obtained through self-assembly. The 2-D sheet structure in 4 was formed by exploiting the 1D-chain structures of Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4 that are bridged by sodium atoms through the cyano groups of their Ni(mnt)2 moieties. Subsequently, in order to interrupt interactions among the Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4 building units in the crystal, complex 4 was reacted with a crown ether (18-crown-6), which captured the sodium cations through host-guest interactions. In fact, the Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4 monomer unit of [Na2(18-crown-16)]2[Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4] (5) was isolated through crystal packing. We determined that the Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4 building unit controls the dimensionality of the coordination polymer, from the monomer to the 2-D sheet structure.

elements.content: Molecular packing of complex 1 viewed from the c-axis direction.
elements.clean_text: 1  Molecular packing of complex 1 viewed from the c-axis direction.

elements.content: The 1-D chain structures of complexes 1–3 were obtained through the reactions of (NBu4)2[M­(mnt)2] and CuI in dry THF under argon. Complexes 1–3 formed coordination polymers with the doubly bridged 1-D chain structure of the Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4 unit in which two copper atoms are coordinated to the nitrogen atoms of the cyano groups of neighboring Ni­(mnt)2 moieties. In the crystal-packed structures of 1–3, there are no direct interactions between the 1-D chain structures of these complexes in order to accommodate the bulky NBu4 cations. We assume that the interactions between the 1-D chain structures can be influenced by changing the bulky cation to a small cation during synthesis, as shown in .
elements.clean_text: The 1-D chain structures of complexes 1-3 were obtained through the reactions of (NBu4)2[M(mnt)2] and CuI in dry THF under argon. Complexes 1-3 formed coordination polymers with the doubly bridged 1-D chain structure of the Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4 unit in which two copper atoms are coordinated to the nitrogen atoms of the cyano groups of neighboring Ni(mnt)2 moieties. In the crystal-packed structures of 1-3, there are no direct interactions between the 1-D chain structures of these complexes in order to accommodate the bulky NBu4 cations. We assume that the interactions between the 1-D chain structures can be influenced by changing the bulky cation to a small cation during synthesis, as shown in .

elements.clean_text: 1  Synthesis of a 2-D Polymer with the Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4 Building Unit

elements.content: By adopting a similar approach to those used for the preparation of complexes 1–3, thin single crystals of complex 4 were successfully obtained by the reaction of Na­(mnt)2, NiCl2·6H2O, and CuI under Ar, using dry THF as the solvent. The crystal structure of 4 was solved by synchrotron radiation X-ray crystallography in order to accurately measure the weak diffraction intensities.
elements.clean_text: By adopting a similar approach to those used for the preparation of complexes 1-3, thin single crystals of complex 4 were successfully obtained by the reaction of Na(mnt)2, NiCl2⋅6H2O, and CuI under Ar, using dry THF as the solvent. The crystal structure of 4 was solved by synchrotron radiation X-ray crystallography in order to accurately measure the weak diffraction intensities.

elements.content: The crystal structure of complex 4 exhibits a doubly bridged 2-D sheet formed through the bridging of the cyano groups of the Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4 units of neighboring 1-D chain structures by sodium atoms. The molecular structure of 4 is shown in in which the THF solvents molecules and disordered atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: The crystal structure of complex 4 exhibits a doubly bridged 2-D sheet formed through the bridging of the cyano groups of the Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4 units of neighboring 1-D chain structures by sodium atoms. The molecular structure of 4 is shown in  in which the THF solvents molecules and disordered atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Molecular structure of complex 4. THF solvent molecules and disordered atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 2  Molecular structure of complex 4. THF solvent molecules and disordered atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The Ni­(mnt)2 moiety in complex 4 retains the planar structure of the single molecular [Ni­(mnt)2]2– anion, and the Ni–S bond lengths (2.180 Å av.) in 4 are almost the same as those of the monomeric [Ni­(mnt)2]2– anion (2.175 Å av.), indicating that charge transfer from the Ni­(mnt)2 moiety to the eight-membered Cu4I4 ring in complex 4 does not occur. Since 4 does not exhibit a superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) signal, the nickel atom in this complex is inferred to have remained in the +2 valence state. One side of the Ni­(mnt)2 moiety is covered by the disordered eight-membered Cu4I4 ring, with copper atoms positioned close to the sulfur atoms of the mnt moieties. Within the eight-membered ring, copper and iodine atoms are alternately connected, with the Cu–I distances ranging from 2.500(6) to 2.696(12) Å. There are four crystallographically independent copper atoms; Cu1 and Cu3 have distorted tetrahedral coordinations, with two I atoms, one S, and one N atom each, while Cu2, Cu4A, and Cu4B exhibit distorted trigonal planar coordinations, with two iodine atoms and one sulfur atom each. It should be noted that the Ni1···Cu2 distance of 2.8427(15) Å is shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of these two atoms, indicative of a weak interaction. A sodium cation is connected to two iodides of the eight-membered Cu4I4 ring. Furthermore, three THF molecules are coordinated to this sodium cation. In complex 1, each copper atom is located almost directly above the corresponding sulfur atom of the Ni­(mnt)2 moiety to form a template. However, the Cu4I4 crown motif in complex 4 is not only distorted from the templated planar NiS4 structure, it is also disordered over two positions, with occupancies of 59% and 41%. The copper and iodine atoms are alternately connected within the eight-membered ring structure, as was observed for complex 1. A sodium cation has also been captured by the Cu4I4 crown motif in complex 4. The flexible Cu4I4 crown motif is proposed to be able to capture a variety of atoms or molecules; such a material may act as a molecular adsorbent through electrostatic interactions. Copper atoms are coordinated to the nitrogen atoms of the cyano groups of neighboring molecular units, which are doubly bridged anionic 1-D polymers consisting of [Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4]2– units. In complex 4, the cyano groups of the [Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4]2– units of neighboring 1-D chains are bridged by sodium atoms, resulting in the formation of a doubly bridged 2-D sheet structure, as shown in .
elements.clean_text: The Ni(mnt)2 moiety in complex 4 retains the planar structure of the single molecular [Ni(mnt)2]2- anion, and the Ni-S bond lengths (2.180 Å av.) in 4 are almost the same as those of the monomeric [Ni(mnt)2]2- anion (2.175 Å av.), indicating that charge transfer from the Ni(mnt)2 moiety to the eight-membered Cu4I4 ring in complex 4 does not occur. Since 4 does not exhibit a superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) signal, the nickel atom in this complex is inferred to have remained in the +2 valence state. One side of the Ni(mnt)2 moiety is covered by the disordered eight-membered Cu4I4 ring, with copper atoms positioned close to the sulfur atoms of the mnt moieties. Within the eight-membered ring, copper and iodine atoms are alternately connected, with the Cu-I distances ranging from 2.500(6) to 2.696(12) Å. There are four crystallographically independent copper atoms; Cu1 and Cu3 have distorted tetrahedral coordinations, with two I atoms, one S, and one N atom each, while Cu2, Cu4A, and Cu4B exhibit distorted trigonal planar coordinations, with two iodine atoms and one sulfur atom each. It should be noted that the Ni1⋅⋅⋅Cu2 distance of 2.8427(15) Å is shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of these two atoms, indicative of a weak interaction. A sodium cation is connected to two iodides of the eight-membered Cu4I4 ring. Furthermore, three THF molecules are coordinated to this sodium cation. In complex 1, each copper atom is located almost directly above the corresponding sulfur atom of the Ni(mnt)2 moiety to form a template. However, the Cu4I4 crown motif in complex 4 is not only distorted from the templated planar NiS4 structure, it is also disordered over two positions, with occupancies of 59% and 41%. The copper and iodine atoms are alternately connected within the eight-membered ring structure, as was observed for complex 1. A sodium cation has also been captured by the Cu4I4 crown motif in complex 4. The flexible Cu4I4 crown motif is proposed to be able to capture a variety of atoms or molecules; such a material may act as a molecular adsorbent through electrostatic interactions. Copper atoms are coordinated to the nitrogen atoms of the cyano groups of neighboring molecular units, which are doubly bridged anionic 1-D polymers consisting of [Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4]2- units. In complex 4, the cyano groups of the [Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4]2- units of neighboring 1-D chains are bridged by sodium atoms, resulting in the formation of a doubly bridged 2-D sheet structure, as shown in .

elements.content: Two-dimensional sheet structure of complex 4. THF solvent molecules and disordered atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 3  Two-dimensional sheet structure of complex 4. THF solvent molecules and disordered atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: We next assume that the 1-D chain structure consisting of the Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4 building units such as complex 1 can be obtained through the capture of the sodium atoms in the 2D sheet structure of complex 4 by 18-crown-6. A single crystal of complex 5 was obtained when an equivalent amount of 18-crown-6, based on the sodium atoms, was added to the reaction solution of 4, as shown in .
elements.clean_text: We next assume that the 1-D chain structure consisting of the Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4 building units such as complex 1 can be obtained through the capture of the sodium atoms in the 2D sheet structure of complex 4 by 18-crown-6. A single crystal of complex 5 was obtained when an equivalent amount of 18-crown-6, based on the sodium atoms, was added to the reaction solution of 4, as shown in .

elements.clean_text: 2  Synthesis of Monomeric Complex 5 with the Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4 Building Unit

elements.content: The crystal structure of complex 5 was also solved by synchrotron radiation X-ray diffraction. The molecular structure of the [Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4]2– monomer unit of complex 5 is shown in . In complex 5, the sodium atom originally bound to THF molecules has been captured by 18-crown-6 through host–guest interactions, as expected. However, the [Na­(18-crown-6)­(THF)2]+ cation is prohibited from participating in the formation of the coordination polymer since Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4 is used as the building unit. The conformation of the eight-membered Cu4I4 ring in complex 5 is different from that of the coordination polymers of complexes 1–4. The square arrangement of the copper atoms in the Cu4I4 crown motif is formed by exploiting the sulfur atoms in the Ni­(mnt)2 moiety as a template, as was observed for complexes 1–4.
elements.clean_text: The crystal structure of complex 5 was also solved by synchrotron radiation X-ray diffraction. The molecular structure of the [Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4]2- monomer unit of complex 5 is shown in . In complex 5, the sodium atom originally bound to THF molecules has been captured by 18-crown-6 through host-guest interactions, as expected. However, the [Na(18-crown-6)(THF)2]+ cation is prohibited from participating in the formation of the coordination polymer since Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4 is used as the building unit. The conformation of the eight-membered Cu4I4 ring in complex 5 is different from that of the coordination polymers of complexes 1-4. The square arrangement of the copper atoms in the Cu4I4 crown motif is formed by exploiting the sulfur atoms in the Ni(mnt)2 moiety as a template, as was observed for complexes 1-4.

elements.content: Molecular structure of the [Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4]2– unit in monomeric complex 5.
elements.clean_text: 4  Molecular structure of the [Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4]2- unit in monomeric complex 5.

elements.content: However, the Cu4I4 crown motif and the nitrogen atoms of the cyano groups of the Ni­(mnt)2 moiety are not connected to neighboring Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4 building units. Therefore, the Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4 monomer retains its C 2 symmetry axis, which lies normal to the Ni­(mnt)2 plane and passes through the Ni atom. The average Ni–S bond length in the Ni­(mnt)2 moiety of 5 is 2.171 Å, which is similar to that of the monomeric [Ni­(mnt)2]2– anion (2.175 Å); we conclude that no charge is transferred from the Ni­(mnt)2 moiety to the eight-membered Cu4I4 ring in complex 5. Since no SQUID signal was observed for complex 5, the nickel atom in complex 5 has clearly retained its +2 valence state. The copper and iodine atoms in the Cu4I4 crown motif are connected alternately, with Cu–I distances ranging from 2.479(2) to 2.570(2) Å. Since the Cu4I4 crown motif in 5 does not coordinate to any neighboring molecules and is only bound to the sulfur atoms of the Ni­(mnt)2 moiety, the Cu–I bond distances in 5 are smaller than those in complexes 1–4. It should be noted that the Cu1···Cu2 and Cu3···Cu4 bond lengths in the crown motif of complex 5 are 2.651(3) and 2.657(3) Å, respectively. Weak interactions exist between the copper atoms in the Cu4I4 crown motif since those distances are shorter than the sums of the van der Waals radii of the atoms involved. In complexes 1–4, two copper atoms in the eight-membered Cu4I4 ring interact with the center metal atoms of the [M­(mnt)2]2– moiety; the Ni···Cu distances range from 2.917(2) to 2.953(2) Å and are shorter than the sums of the van der Waals radii, indicative of weak interactions, similar to those in complexes 1–4. The crystal packing structure of complex 5 is shown in in which the monomeric structures and the Na­(18-crown-6)­(THF)2 cations are illustrated using ball–stick and space-filling models, respectively. The [Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4]2– units are surrounded by Na­(18-crown-6)­(THF)2 cations, and the Na atoms are encapsulated by 18-crown-6, resulting in the crystallization of the monomeric complex 5.
elements.clean_text: However, the Cu4I4 crown motif and the nitrogen atoms of the cyano groups of the Ni(mnt)2 moiety are not connected to neighboring Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4 building units. Therefore, the Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4 monomer retains its C 2 symmetry axis, which lies normal to the Ni(mnt)2 plane and passes through the Ni atom. The average Ni-S bond length in the Ni(mnt)2 moiety of 5 is 2.171 Å, which is similar to that of the monomeric [Ni(mnt)2]2- anion (2.175 Å); we conclude that no charge is transferred from the Ni(mnt)2 moiety to the eight-membered Cu4I4 ring in complex 5. Since no SQUID signal was observed for complex 5, the nickel atom in complex 5 has clearly retained its +2 valence state. The copper and iodine atoms in the Cu4I4 crown motif are connected alternately, with Cu-I distances ranging from 2.479(2) to 2.570(2) Å. Since the Cu4I4 crown motif in 5 does not coordinate to any neighboring molecules and is only bound to the sulfur atoms of the Ni(mnt)2 moiety, the Cu-I bond distances in 5 are smaller than those in complexes 1-4. It should be noted that the Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu2 and Cu3⋅⋅⋅Cu4 bond lengths in the crown motif of complex 5 are 2.651(3) and 2.657(3) Å, respectively. Weak interactions exist between the copper atoms in the Cu4I4 crown motif since those distances are shorter than the sums of the van der Waals radii of the atoms involved. In complexes 1-4, two copper atoms in the eight-membered Cu4I4 ring interact with the center metal atoms of the [M(mnt)2]2- moiety; the Ni⋅⋅⋅Cu distances range from 2.917(2) to 2.953(2) Å and are shorter than the sums of the van der Waals radii, indicative of weak interactions, similar to those in complexes 1-4. The crystal packing structure of complex 5 is shown in  in which the monomeric structures and the Na(18-crown-6)(THF)2 cations are illustrated using ball-stick and space-filling models, respectively. The [Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4]2- units are surrounded by Na(18-crown-6)(THF)2 cations, and the Na atoms are encapsulated by 18-crown-6, resulting in the crystallization of the monomeric complex 5.

elements.content: Molecular packing of complex 5 viewed from the b-axis direction.
elements.clean_text: 5  Molecular packing of complex 5 viewed from the b-axis direction.

elements.content:
It should be noted that the planar structure of the Ni­(mnt)2 moiety is slightly bent toward the side opposite to that covered by Cu4I4, as shown in .

The distance between the plane containing the NiS4 atoms and that containing the N atoms of the cyano groups is 0.44 Å. The main difference between monomeric complex 5 and complexes 1 and 4 is that the Cu4I4 crown motif and the cyano groups are not connected to neighboring Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4 units. The bond lengths in the cyano groups of 1, 4, and 5 are in the typical range (1.12–1.154 Å). The IR spectra of complexes 1, 4, and 5 exhibit bands for their respective cyano groups at 2199, 2202, and 2209 cm–1; these values are not significantly different to the typical stretching frequency of a cyano group. The planar structure of the Ni­(mnt)2 moiety in complex 5 is bent as a result of the copper atoms that are not coordinated to the cyano groups of the Cu4I4 crown motif but are coordinated to the sulfur atoms of the Ni­(mnt)2 moiety instead. In monomeric complex 5, the electronic charge distribution is proposed to be localized from the copper to the sulfur atoms of Ni­(mnt)2, in contrast to complexes 1 and 4.

The main difference between monomeric complex 5 and complexes 1 and 4 is that the Cu4I4 crown motif and the cyano groups are not connected to neighboring Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4 units. The bond lengths in the cyano groups of 1, 4, and 5 are in the typical range (1.12-1.154 Å). The IR spectra of complexes 1, 4, and 5 exhibit bands for their respective cyano groups at 2199, 2202, and 2209 cm-1; these values are not significantly different to the typical stretching frequency of a cyano group. The planar structure of the Ni(mnt)2 moiety in complex 5 is bent as a result of the copper atoms that are not coordinated to the cyano groups of the Cu4I4 crown motif but are coordinated to the sulfur atoms of the Ni(mnt)2 moiety instead. In monomeric complex 5, the electronic charge distribution is proposed to be localized from the copper to the sulfur atoms of Ni(mnt)2, in contrast to complexes 1 and 4.

elements.content: Side view of the [Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4]2– unit in monomeric complex 5. The two blue-colored planes pass through the NiS4 atoms and the N atoms of the cyano groups.
elements.clean_text: 6  Side view of the [Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4]2- unit in monomeric complex 5. The two blue-colored planes pass through the NiS4 atoms and the N atoms of the cyano groups.

elements.content: Complexes 4 and 5 were subjected to differential thermogravimetric analysis (DTA) after vacuum drying, the results of which are shown in Figures S7 and S8, respectively. There were no remarkable endothermic peaks in the DTA curves of complexes 4 and 5, and the weight losses of these complexes were less than 10% to at least 500 K. These thermogravimetry results suggest that compounds 4 and 5 are thermostable.
elements.clean_text: Complexes 4 and 5 were subjected to differential thermogravimetric analysis (DTA) after vacuum drying, the results of which are shown in Figures S7 and S8, respectively. There were no remarkable endothermic peaks in the DTA curves of complexes 4 and 5, and the weight losses of these complexes were less than 10% to at least 500 K. These thermogravimetry results suggest that compounds 4 and 5 are thermostable.

elements.content: In conclusion, interactions between the 1-D chain structures of complex 4 and the eight-membered Cu4I4 ring are obtained by changing the bulky NBu4 cation to the small sodium cation. A doubly bridged 2-D sheet structure was formed by bridging the cyano groups of the Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4 units of neighboring 1-D chain structures with sodium atoms. Subsequently, monomeric complex 5 was formed by capturing the sodium cations in 4 with 18-crown-6. The dominance of the coordination polymer or the monomer was facilitated by selecting the appropriate countercation to the Ni­(mnt)2Cu4I4 building unit. Furthermore, the eight-membered Cu4I4 crown motif of complex 4 captures a sodium cation. With this feature in mind, the flexible Cu4I4 crown motif is proposed to be capable of capturing atoms or molecules of various sizes; such a material may find use as a molecular adsorbent through electrostatic interactions. An investigation into the adsorptivity of the Cu4I4 crown motif will be the subject of future research.

A doubly bridged 2-D sheet structure was formed by bridging the cyano groups of the Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4 units of neighboring 1-D chain structures with sodium atoms. Subsequently, monomeric complex 5 was formed by capturing the sodium cations in 4 with 18-crown-6. The dominance of the coordination polymer or the monomer was facilitated by selecting the appropriate countercation to the Ni(mnt)2Cu4I4 building unit. Furthermore, the eight-membered Cu4I4 crown motif of complex 4 captures a sodium cation. With this feature in mind, the flexible Cu4I4 crown motif is proposed to be capable of capturing atoms or molecules of various sizes; such a material may find use as a molecular adsorbent through electrostatic interactions. An investigation into the adsorptivity of the Cu4I4 crown motif will be the subject of future research.

metadata.title:
Controlled Self-Assembly of a 2‑D Sheet Coordination
Polymer and Monomer Containing an Eight-Membered Cu4I4 Crown Motif
